importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, when singer Kenny Loggins formally objected to the use of his music in a video attributed to President Trump.
The date when The White Stripes dropped their copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump, indicating a shift in legal actions related to political use of music.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the 'No Kings' protests occurred, and when the AI-generated video by Trump was posted, sparking public and legal responses.

keyTakeAways: Kenny Loggins is requesting that the audio of his song 'Danger Zone' be removed from a fake video posted by President Trump on Truth Social.
The video falsely depicts a crown-wearing Trump in a fighter jet with 'KING TRUMP' emblazoned, playing 'Danger Zone' as sludge is dumped over protesters in Times Square.
Loggins claims the use of his performance is unauthorized and expresses concern that political content using music can deepen division among Americans.
Although such use is generally legal with proper licensing, performers can specifically prohibit use in campaign ads, and many artists choose to publicly object to avoid misuse.
Other musicians, including The White Stripes and the estate of Isaac Hayes, have previously sued Trump over political use of music, with the Hayes case still ongoing.
The video appears to be a response to the widespread 'No Kings' protests across the U.S., which were organized in opposition to Trump's crown imagery.
The White House declined to comment directly on Loggins' request, instead sharing a film still from 'Top Gun' with the caption 'I FEEL THE NEED FOR SPEED'.

namedEntities.name: Kenny Loggins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Singer-songwriter and performer of the song 'Danger Zone'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Loggins is directly involved in the controversy, as he has publicly objected to the unauthorized use of his song in a political video by President Trump.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. President who posted the AI-generated video featuring a crown-wearing figure in a fighter jet playing 'Danger Zone'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central figure in the political controversy, as the video was posted by him on Truth Social and appears to be a response to the 'No Kings' protests.

namedEntities.name: Truth Social
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Social media platform used by President Trump to post the controversial video
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform is where the video was originally shared, making it a key location in the dissemination and controversy of the content.

namedEntities.name: Danger Zone
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Music song performed by Kenny Loggins, originally from the film 'Top Gun'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The song is central to the controversy, as it is being used in an AI-generated video without permission, prompting Loggins' objection.

namedEntities.name: Top Gun
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: 1986 film that features the song 'Danger Zone'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The origin of the song that is being used in the video, linking the music to the film and its cultural context.

namedEntities.name: Giorgio Moroder
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Composer who co-wrote the song 'Danger Zone'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the song's creators, contributing to the intellectual property rights involved in the controversy.

namedEntities.name: Tom Whitlock
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Songwriter who co-wrote the song 'Danger Zone'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another co-creator of the song, thus part of the legal rights holders involved in the dispute.

namedEntities.name: No Kings protests
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Protests across the U.S. that oppose the idea of a 'king' in politics, inspired by Trump's crown imagery
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The protests provide context for the video's creation, as it appears to be a response to public opposition to Trump's symbolic 'kingship'.

namedEntities.name: The White Stripes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Music band that filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump, which was later dropped
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They represent a precedent of musicians challenging political use of their music, reinforcing the broader issue of artist rights in political discourse.

namedEntities.name: Isaac Hayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musician whose estate filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump and related entities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another example of a musician objecting to political use of their work, with the case still ongoing.

namedEntities.name: Turning Point Action
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Activist group sued by the estate of Isaac Hayes over political use of music
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Part of the legal context involving the political misuse of music by Trump-aligned groups.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive office of the U.S. President, which posted a fake image on X in response to the protests
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House responded to the protests with a fake image, demonstrating institutional involvement in the political imagery dispute.

namedEntities.name: X (formerly Twitter)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Social media platform used by the White House to post a fake image of Trump and Vice President Vance with crowns
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform was used to amplify the political imagery and counter the 'No Kings' protests.

namedEntities.name: Davis R. Ingle
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: White House spokesperson who did not respond directly to NPR's questions
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the official White House stance, which chose not to address Loggins' request directly and instead shared a 'Top Gun' film still.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Singer-songwriter Kenny Loggins has formally objected to the use of his performance of 'Danger Zone' in a fake AI-generated video posted by President Donald Trump on Truth Social. The video, depicting a crown-wearing Trump in a fighter jet with 'KING TRUMP' emblazoned, plays 'Danger Zone' as sludge is dumped over protesters in Times Square â€” a scene seemingly in response to the widespread 'No Kings' protests across the U.S. Loggins asserts that the use of his music is unauthorized and expresses concern that such politically charged content can deepen societal division. While the use of music in political videos is generally legal if rights are properly compensated, performers can prohibit specific uses, especially in campaign-related content. This incident follows a pattern of musicians, including The White Stripes and the estate of Isaac Hayes, challenging Trump's political use of their music, with the Hayes case still ongoing. The White House declined to comment directly on Loggins' request, instead sharing a film still from 'Top Gun' with the caption 'I FEEL THE NEED FOR SPEED'.
title: Trump's fake video featured 'Danger Zone.' Musician Kenny Loggins wants it scrubbed
